div.p: In reply to your favor of 15th. inst we beg to call your attention to the following information respecting the Gt. North of Scotland Ry. Co.

div.p: The Optimal Preference Stock is the only Preference in this Company.—

The other Stock to which we alluded in our last is “North Eastern—Berwick 4% Preference” This stock, the amount of which is about £2.000.000, is protected by an ordinary share capital of £6.427.345 upon which dividends have been paid of late varying from 412 to 6%
Last Feby. twelvemonth the stock touched par or 100. & you will now see it quoted in “the Times” nominal price is only 96.8
It is impossible to give the amount of “Berwick” Loans, as the Loans on the
are a joint charge on the three associated Companies The total amount is £5.500.000 against a total share capital of £16.198.295

We are Dear Sir | Yours respectfully | RS. & JS. Scrimgeour Co

P.S. | We may perhaps state that this is so far a favorable time for effecting the operation you have in view that there is just now a parcel of “Berwick” stock on the market, while at times it is impossible to buy it at all.

CD’s letter to the stockbroking firm Scrimgeour & Co. has not been found. The proprietors of the firm were Robert Shedden Scrimgeour and John Shedden Scrimgeour (London, England, Stock Exchange membership applications, 1802–1924 Ancestry.com, accessed 14 September 2022).

CD’s Investment book (Down House MS) records that on 22 June 1859 he purchased 90 preference shares in the Great North of Scotland Railway Company at 1112, adding to the 180 shares he bought in April and June 1858. On 1 July 1859, he bought 9000 preference shares in the North Eastern Berwick Railway at ‘4 per cent (with perpetual power of changing into ordinary shares) at 9634’. The latter shares cost him £8707 10s.
